title: How to Recover Oily Granite

methods.name: Treating the Stain with a Poultice

steps.headline: Wipe any excess oil off the granite’s surface with a clean paper towel.
steps.description: Try to soak up as much of the oil as you can if there’s any left on the surface so it doesn’t keep absorbing into the stone. Replace the paper towel when it gets dirty so you don’t spread the oil back on your countertops. Avoid using rags or cloths since oil could leave stains on them.

steps.headline: Create a poultice paste from 2 parts baking soda and 1 part water.
steps.description: Pour the baking soda and water in a small bowl so you have enough to cover the stain. Mix them together with a plastic spatula until they’re thoroughly combined into a paste with a similar consistency to peanut butter. Add more baking soda if it feels too runny, or pour in water if it’s too thick to work with. You can also buy stain remover powder made for granite from a hardware store. Mix it with water so it has a similar consistency. Avoid using vinegar or hydrogen peroxide for your poultice since it can discolor or damage your granite.Tip: Test a coin-sized amount of the poultice in an inconspicuous spot on the granite, such as an area that’s normally covered by an appliance, to see if it affects the color.

steps.headline: Spread the poultice over the oil stain with a plastic spatula.
steps.description: Use your spatula to scoop the poultice on top of the stain. Press the poultice down firmly so it extends about 1 inch (2.5 cm) past the edges of the stain. Make the poultice about ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) thick so it’s able to dry out within a day. If you have multiple oil stains on the granite, use enough poultice to cover each of them.

steps.headline: Cover the poultice with plastic wrap and tape down the edges.
steps.description: Rip off a piece of plastic wrap that extends past the poultice’s edges by about 1–2 inches (2.5–5.1 cm). Press the wrap flat against the granite and poultice so it makes firm contact with them. Use masking tape around the edges of the plastic wrap to hold it in place so it doesn’t come off while you’re treating your stain. Avoid using duct tape since it can leave sticky residue on your countertops. You don’t have to tape the edges down, but the plastic wrap may move or blow away and make the poultice dry too quickly and make it less effective. If you need to cover oily sections that are wider than the plastic wrap, overlap the pieces by 1 inch (2.5 cm) and tape them together.

steps.headline: Poke holes in the plastic wrap to allow airflow.
steps.description: Use a fork or safety pin to poke holes every 1–2 inches (2.5–5.1 cm) in the plastic wrap. Keep the holes evenly spaced so air can flow around the poultice so it’s able to slowly dry out and draw the stain out. Be careful not to scratch the granite with the pin or fork.

steps.headline: Leave the poultice on the granite for 24 hours or until it dries.
steps.description: Allow the poultice to set on the granite undisturbed so it can work the most effectively. Usually, the poultice will dry overnight, but it may take longer depending on how much you used and the size of the stain. Lift the corner of the plastic wrap and touch the poultice to make sure it’s dry before moving on. It may take up to 2 days for the poultice to dry. If you’re using a commercial stain remover powder, follow the instructions on the packaging since they may have different recommended waiting times.

steps.headline: Scrape the poultice off with a plastic scraper.
steps.description: Remove the plastic wrap from your granite and put the blade of a plastic scraper next to the dried poultice. Keep the blade flat against the granite and push it through the poultice so it breaks apart. Continue scraping off the poultice until there isn’t anymore stuck on your countertops. Then sweep the residue into a dustpan so you can throw it away. If you have trouble using a plastic scraper on the poultice, try using a razor blade. Keep the blade flat against the granite’s surface so you don’t scratch it, and be careful so you don’t cut yourself.

steps.headline: Rinse the area with warm water and dry it with a towel.
steps.description: Wet a clean towel with warm water from your sink and wipe any of the poultice residue off of your granite. Immediately use another towel to dry off the granite, or else you may leave water stains on the surface. If you still notice the oil stain, try making another poultice and repeating the process until the stain disappears.

steps.headline: Seal the granite if water droplets absorb into it after 15 minutes.
steps.description: Place a few drops of water on your granite and allow them to sit on the surface for about 15 minutes. If you notice the water beads up and stays on the surface, then you don’t have to reseal the granite. If the drops appear flat or they spread out and darken the stone, then it’s time to reseal your counters. Immediately wipe the water off with a towel to avoid water stains. Typically, you will need to reseal granite once every 2–3 years since it wears away with daily use.Warning: Avoid adding sealant to granite if water still beads on the surface since it will create an unattractive hazy finish.

steps.headline: Wash the granite with dish soap and isopropyl alcohol 1 day before sealing it.
steps.description: Combine 1 teaspoon (4.9 ml) of liquid dish soap, 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of isopropyl alcohol, and 1 US pint (470 ml) of cool water in a spray bottle. Apply the cleaner directly to your counters and wipe it off with a microfiber cloth using circular motions. Make sure you remove all of the cleaner so it doesn’t dry on the surface of your granite. After you clean, wait at least 24 hours before applying the sealant. If you try to apply the sealant immediately after cleaning it, then it will not bond with the granite properly and won’t be as effective.

steps.headline: Spray the surface of the granite with a commercial sealant.
steps.description: Hold the spray bottle of sealant about 6 inches (15 cm) away and spray it generously onto your granite counters. Make sure you get an even layer of the sealant across the entire surface to ensure it seals properly. You can buy a bottle of granite or stone sealant from your local hardware store. Usually, 1 US quart (0.95 L) of sealant covers about 150–250 square feet (14–23 m) of granite. Open windows or turn on a vent fan in the room where you’re working since sealant can create harmful fumes. If it’s raining, avoid opening windows next to your granite since water could get on it and ruin the seal.

steps.headline: Spread the sealant over the surface with a microfiber cloth.
steps.description: Hold a microfiber cloth above your countertop so it barely touches the surface. Drag the cloth in straight back and forth motions across the granite to smooth out the sealant so it creates a flat, even layer. Avoid pressing the cloth against the surface, or else you may remove the sealant. You can also use a paper towel if you don’t have a microfiber cloth.

steps.headline: Allow the sealant to absorb into the granite for 15 minutes.
steps.description: Leave the area alone for at least 15 minutes so the sealant has time to soak in. Avoid touching or setting anything on top of your counters while the sealant dries, or else it won’t properly bond with the stone. Check the instructions on the sealant’s packaging since they may recommend letting the sealant soak in for a longer amount of time. Avoid leaving the sealant on your granite longer than the recommended time since it may cause discoloration.

steps.headline: Use a clean microfiber cloth to wipe off any excess sealant.
steps.description: Work in circular motions across your countertop to lift up sealant that hasn’t soaked into the stone. Be sure to wipe the entire area you sealed, or else the residual sealant could discolor your granite.

steps.headline: Avoid using or cleaning the granite for 48 hours so the sealant has time to cure.
steps.description: Keep items off of the countertop while the sealant cures so you don’t destroy the seal. Wait for the recommended amount of time on the sealant’s package, which is usually around 2 days, before using the granite as you normally would. Some granite sealants require a second coat, so check the packaging on the sealant you’re using to see what it recommends.
